decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be begun before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.
REASON
To comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.
The temporary use hereby permitted shall be discontinued on or before 5 years from the date of this decision notice.
REASON

In order to minimise the impact of the development on the Green Belt, in accordance with paragraphs 143 to 150 of the NPPF (2021), Policy G2 of the London Plan and relevant guidance in the Local Plan.

The development hereby permitted shall not be carried out except in complete accordance with the details shown on the submitted plan numbers 100151MVH-MMD-00-XX-DR-C-0009 Rev P2 and THHR-ACM-MV-ZZ-DR-E-6002 Rev P01 and shall thereafter be retained/maintained for as long as the development remains in existence.
REASON
To ensure the development complies with the provisions Hillingdon Local Plan Parts 1 (November 2012) and 2 (January 2020) and the London Plan (2021).

Prior to first use of the hereby approved temporary car parks, a landscaping scheme shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority detailing how the land subject of this application will be used after the period of 5 years when the approved use is discontinued. After approval of the landscaping scheme by the local planning authority, the landscaping scheme shall be implemented and maintained.
REASON

To ensure that the proposed development will preserve and enhance the visual amenities of the locality in compliance with policies DMHB 11, DMHB 14 of the Hillingdon Local Plan Part 2 (2020), to ensure that the proposal protects and where possible enhances the site biological value in line with policies EM7 of the Local Plan and G6 of the London Plan and to protect the Green Belt in accordance with the relevant policy guidance set out within Local Plan Part 1 (November 2012) and 2 (January 2020), as well as the London Plan (2021) and NPPF (2021).
No development shall take place until a lighting and landscaping scheme has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The scheme shall include:
a. Soft landscaping improvements to enhance the sites biological value including the provision of log piles and brash piles.
b. Car Parking Layouts
c. Hard Surfacing Materials
d. Other structures (such as car park furniture, ancillary machinery and other objects)
e. A landscaping scheme which shall be implemented after the period of 5 years when the use is discontinued.
Thereafter the development shall be carried out and maintained in full accordance with the approved details.
REASON

To ensure that the proposed development will preserve and enhance the visual amenities of the locality and provide adequate facilities in compliance with policies DMHB 11, DMHB 14, DMEI 1 and DMT 6 of the Hillingdon Local Plan Part 2 (2020), to ensure that the proposal protects and where possible enhances the site biological va

Notwithstanding any external lighting details shown on the approved plans or lighting specification document (THHR-ACM-MV-ZZ-SP-E-6001), details of all proposed lighting shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the relevant part of the work is begun. The details shall include measures to prevent light spill such as:
- fitting lights with accessories such as baffles hoods or louvres to minimise light spill;
- using rear shields to stop back-light spilling onto the woodland and scrub habitats.
- using downward directional lighting
- Using short columns; and
- where possible, motion sensors or short-timers should be used.
The development shall be carried out in accordance with the details so approved and maintained thereafter.
REASON
To protect bats and the sites biological value in line with policies EM7 of the Local Plan and G6 of the London Plan, as well as section 15 of the NPPF (2021).

No development shall take place until a Construction Environmental Management Plan (or similar document) detailing measures to control dust deposition, pollution/spillage, noise, vibration or lighting pollution during construction has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The development shall be carried out in strict accordance with the approved CEMP thereafter.
REASON

To protect wildlife within the nearby woodland and the sites biological value in line with policies EM7 of the Local Plan and G6 of the London Plan, as well as section 15 of the To protect the Green Belt in accordance with the relevant policy guidance set out within Local Plan Part 1 (November 2012) and 2 (January 2020), as well as the London Plan (2021) and NPPF (2021).NPPF (2021).

The active nests of all wild birds are protected under the Wildlife & Countryside Act 1981 (As amended). An active nest is one being built, containing eggs or chicks, or on which fledged chicks are still dependent.
All clearance, conversion and demolition work in association with the approved scheme shall be carried out outside of the bird nesting season which runs from March to September inclusive.

Note: If it is necessary for work to commence in the nesting season then a precommencement inspection of the vegetation and buildings for active bird nests should be carried out. If vegetation cannot be clearly seen to be clear of bird's nests then an experienced ecologist should be called in to carry out the check. Only if there are no active nests present should work be allowed to commence.

Any tree (suitable for roosting bats) which is to be pruned or removed as part of the proposed development, shall first be inspected by a bat licensed ecologist (prior to the start of works). If a bat roost is found a European Protected Species Mitigation Licence (EPSML) from Natural England may be required. Evidence of such license being approved shall be submitted to the Local Planning Authority prior to commencement of the works.

During the construction phase, all deep holes and trenches should be covered overnight and/or the provision of planked escape routes for any wildlife that may fall in. In addition, any liquids held on-site will be stored in a secure lock-up. Additionally and where possible, hoarding should be used around the perimeter of the site to minimise the likelihood of any wild mammals gaining access to the site.
description: Temporary reinstatement of two existing car parks (Car Park A and Chapel Car Park) to provide 176 car parking spaces (61 of the 176 car parking spaces are in existing use) and associated works including access, removal of barriers, surfacing, and installation of lighting, CCTV and new ticket machines.
